semantic_title: Coding of Traumatic Fractures - General Principles and Multiple Coding
section_path: Section I > C. Chapter-Specific Coding Guidelines > 19. Injury, Poisoning, and Certain Other Consequences of External Causes > c. Coding of Traumatic Fractures

content.full_text: The principles of multiple coding of injuries should be followed in coding fractures. Fractures of specified sites are coded individually by site in accordance with both the provisions within categories S02, S12, S22, S32, S42, S49, S52, S59, S62, S72, S79, S82, S89, S92 and the level of detail furnished by medical record content. A fracture not indicated as open or closed should be coded to closed. A fracture not indicated whether displaced or not displaced should be coded to displaced. (Evidence: pg no: 79, L40-L43)
content.summary: General principles for coding traumatic fractures including multiple coding, site-specific coding, and default assumptions for open/closed and displaced status (Evidence: pg no: 79, L40-L43)
key_concepts: Multiple coding principles for fractures (Evidence: pg no: 79, L40-L41)
Individual site-specific coding (Evidence: pg no: 79, L41-L42)
Default to closed fractures when not specified (Evidence: pg no: 79, L43)
Default to displaced fractures when not specified (Evidence: pg no: 79, L43)

detailed_rules.rule_text: The principles of multiple coding of injuries should be followed in coding fractures (Evidence: pg no: 79, L40-L41)
detailed_rules.explanation: Each fracture should be coded separately following general injury coding principles (Evidence: pg no: 79, L40-L41)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Fractures of specified sites are coded individually by site (Evidence: pg no: 79, L41-L42)
detailed_rules.explanation: Each fracture site requires its own specific code based on anatomical location and medical record detail (Evidence: pg no: 79, L41-L42)

detailed_rules.rule_text: A fracture not indicated as open or closed should be coded to closed (Evidence: pg no: 79, L43)
detailed_rules.explanation: When documentation doesn't specify open or closed status, assume closed fracture (Evidence: pg no: 79, L43)

detailed_rules.rule_text: A fracture not indicated whether displaced or not displaced should be coded to displaced (Evidence: pg no: 79, L43)
detailed_rules.explanation: When documentation doesn't specify displacement status, assume displaced fracture (Evidence: pg no: 79, L43)

workflow_steps: Step 1: Identify all fracture sites from documentation
Step 2: Code each fracture site individually
Step 3: Determine open/closed status (default to closed if not specified)
Step 4: Determine displaced status (default to displaced if not specified)
Step 5: Apply appropriate level of detail based on medical record content

references_to.title: Coding of Injuries
references_to.explanation: Fracture coding follows general injury coding principles

coding_scenarios.scenario: Patient with fractures of both radius and ulna
coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Fractures of radius and ulna, status not specified
step_by_step: Step 1: Identify each fracture site (radius and ulna)
Step 3: Apply defaults (closed, displaced) since not specified

correct_coding.rationale: Multiple coding principles require individual site coding with defaults applied (Evidence: pg no: 79, L40-L43)

incorrect_coding.rationale: Each fracture site must be coded individually
incorrect_coding.common_mistake: Using single code for multiple fracture sites

warnings: Always code fractures individually by site (Evidence: pg no: 79, L41-L42)
best_practices: Apply default assumptions when documentation is incomplete (Evidence: pg no: 79, L43)
Follow multiple coding principles for all fractures (Evidence: pg no: 79, L40-L41)
common_mistakes: Not coding each fracture site separately (Evidence: pg no: 79, L41-L42)
Not applying default assumptions for unspecified status (Evidence: pg no: 79, L43)
tips: Default to closed and displaced when not specified (Evidence: pg no: 79, L43)
implementation_notes: Level of detail depends on medical record content
clinical_context: Common in trauma and orthopedic settings
